meaning_mnemonic: Think about it this way. There is a famous fishing lure inventor, working on his best work ever. He’s old, and he’s been trying to make the best fishing lure for the last 50 years, and knows this will be his last invention. Then he figures it out. He takes one <radical>barb</radical>, and connects the end of it to the top of another <radical>barb</radical>. When he does this, he knows his work is finally <kanji>finish</kanji>ed.
You have <radical>fins</radical> in <radical>private</radical>. But, you want the world to see them, so you take them <kanji>public</kanji>.

This kanji is the same as the radical — <kanji>straight</kanji> as straight can be.

It can also mean <kanji>direct</kanji>, because when you go straight to a place, you're going there directly. Depending on the context it can even mean <kanji>fix</kanji>, since fixing something means straightening out all the messed up crooked bits.

If you give a <radical>woman</radical> a <radical>machine</radical> she'll <kanji>begin</kanji> learning how to use it right away. She'll also get it to <kanji>start</kanji> before anyone else could. Women are really good at starting up new machines!
<radical>Run</radical> into <radical>oneself</radical> in a dream and you'll definitely <kanji>wake up</kanji>.

You jump on your <radical>scooter</radical> with a big <radical>bundle</radical> to go as <kanji>fast</kanji> as you can! You have a bundle of pizzas in here, and they need to be delivered as fast as you can get them there!

You don't want to keep all the <radical>alcohol</radical> to yourself (<radical>oneself</radical>), so you <kanji>distribute</kanji> it to all of your friends. Heck, not just your friends, to everyone you can find!

A <radical>tsunami</radical> is an <radical>alcohol</radical>ic beverage containing a lot of <kanji>alcohol</kanji>. It’s 3 different kinds of rums, pineapple juice, and grenadine. It’ll hit you like a tsunami though. This alcoholic drink has a kick to it.
This <radical>building</radical> has a <radical>roof</radical> and will teach you about the <radical>origin</radical> of many things. It's an <kanji>institution</kanji>!

The <radical>thread</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> and <radical>ice</radical> has brought this year to its <kanji>end</kanji>. Once you're in the long thread of winter and ice, you know the year will end soon.
You find some <radical>feathers</radical> that are so perfectly <radical>white</radical>, you want to <kanji>learn</kanji> more about where they came from and what they're made of.

If your <radical>car</radical> runs into a <radical>cloud</radical> you'll <kanji>revolve</kanji> around it instead of going straight through. Clouds are really hard to see through, so even though you're trying not to, you revolve in a tight circle up and around the cloud anyway.

You give your <radical>scooter</radical> to a <radical>turkey</radical> so that it can <kanji>advance</kanji>. The turkey was trying and failing to walk through a crowded street, so out of the goodness of your heart you gave it a scooter so it could advance.

<radical>Flowers</radical> are knocked down by a violent <radical>tsunami</radical>, and swirl through the air to <radical>kiss</radical> your face gently as they <kanji>fall</kanji>. With the tsunami came a great windy storm that blew the flowers down. Amongst all the destruction, it's a pretty sight to watch them fall.

<radical>Flowers</radical> bring beauty to the <radical>world</radical> of <radical>trees</radical>, but the <kanji>leaf</kanji> is what matters the most. <kanji>Leaves</kanji> are how flowers and trees get their nutrients from the sun!

For a <radical>car</radical>, a <radical>tombstone</radical> is <kanji>lightweight</kanji>. Cars are very strong, you see, so something heavy like a tombstone is no match for them. All cars find tombstones to be <kanji>light</kanji> and easy to transport.

While riding your <radical>scooter</radical>, you bang your <radical>forehead</radical> on the <radical>car</radical> in front. Your scooter's wrecked, so you have to <kanji>carry</kanji> it home. You'll need a lot of <kanji>luck</kanji> to get that scooter home safely.

A <radical>gate</radical> with a <radical>lantern</radical> is <kanji>open</kanji> for you. That's convenient, since it's pretty dark out and you might not have seen the open gate without the lantern's help.
You chase a <radical>turkey</radical> up a <radical>tree</radical> to <kanji>collect</kanji> it. At least, you will once you've <kanji>gather</kanji>ed enough turkeys into this one tree.
You can <radical>eat</radical> all you want, but you'll still <radical>lack</radical> something to <kanji>drink</kanji>. You can't live just from eating, you have to drink things too!

You have <radical>spikes</radical> growing out of a <radical>sheep</radical> with <radical>fins</radical>. Turn this thing into a <kanji>business</kanji>! You could totally charge people money to look at it. Sure, you could also donate it to science, but a business-minded person like you knows a business opportunity when you see one. Step right up! Just five dollars for a glance at the rare spiky mer-sheep!

A <radical>tsunami</radical> hit ancient <radical>China</radical> and formed the <kanji>Chinese</kanji> country we know now as... <kanji>China</kanji>!

Sometimes this kanji also means <kanji>man</kanji>. In fact, it used to refer specifically to people of the Han dynasty, but over time evolved into a term for men in specific contexts.

If you've been walking all day, your <radical>foot</radical> is the last thing anyone would want to <radical>kiss</radical>, especially after wandering barefoot down a <kanji>road</kanji>. Your feet are filthy, sweaty, and stinky. Nobody is going to want to kiss those feet.

You blast your <radical>music</radical> loud so it causes a <radical>landslide</radical>, revealing the perfect soil for <kanji>farming</kanji>! Musically moved dirt is perfect for <kanji>agriculture</kanji>.

You look at some <radical>gold</radical> and notice a <radical>fault</radical> in it. You scrape at the fault and see that it's just sprayed with gold paint. It's not gold, it's (comparatively) worthless <kanji>iron</kanji>!
If a <radical>lip ring</radical> (or two in this case) is what you <radical>lack</radical>, it's going to be way easier for you to <kanji>sing</kanji> a <kanji>song</kanji>.

If someone sticks <radical>bamboo</radical> in your <radical>eye</radical> <radical>twenty</radical> times, the first thing your brain does is <kanji>calculate</kanji> how painful it is. Your brain's pain <kanji>calculation</kanji> will determine how you calculate your next move.

If you go up to a <radical>gate</radical> and press your <radical>ear</radical> to it, you'll <kanji>hear</kanji> what's going on on the other side. The people on the other side will have no idea you can hear their conversation.

What you <radical>say</radical> between <radical>five</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>s is a <kanji>language</kanji>. As long as there are five different people saying these same words with their five mouths, it's considered its own language.

You have to <radical>say</radical> what you’re <radical>sell</radical>ing because people don’t like to <kanji>read</kanji>. If they walk right by and don’t read, you better say what you have for sale so they’ll know! Read it out loud to them.

When the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>bird</radical> opens, you're most likely to hear a <kanji>chirp</kanji>. This is how birds communicate. They open their mouths and let out a series of chirps. Chirp chirp chirp!

You can use a long piece of <radical>thread</radical> during <radical>white</radical> <radical>water</radical> rafting as a safety <kanji>line</kanji>. Sure it's thin, but if someone goes overboard even a line of thread is better than nothing. Throw them a line and drag them back aboard!

The <radical>tree</radical> marked with a <radical>yellow</radical> X on the <kanji>side</kanji> of the house is going to get cut down. You’ve marked it with a yellow X so the hired help knows which tree to cut down. There are a lot of trees on the side of the house, but the tree marked with a yellow X is the only one in danger of causing damage to your roof in the event of a storm.

You <radical>say</radical> something about the <radical>circumference</radical> of this area. You've looked around this whole area, making a big circle around it, because you are trying to <kanji>investigate</kanji> something that happened here. You also say this thing in a really quiet <kanji>tone</kanji> of voice, because you don't want the person or thing you're investigating to know you're on to them.
If you're <radical>stand</radical>ing under a <radical>tree</radical> and you <radical>see</radical> your <kanji>parent</kanji>, it's a good chance for a moment of <kanji>intimacy</kanji>.

If you feed a lot of <radical>beans</radical> to a <radical>geoduck</radical>, its <kanji>head</kanji> will grow larger. To a geoduck, beans are a brain food, so by eating beans, it can grow an incredibly large head. Geoducks already look strange enough as it is, let alone with engorged heads.

You <radical>stand</radical> on a <radical>cliff</radical>, a <radical>hair</radical>'s breadth away from the edge, when out of nowhere a <radical>geoduck</radical> slaps you in the <kanji>face</kanji>. The force makes you back away from the edge of the cliff, and your face is all slimy from the geoduck's residue.

A <radical>sick</radical> stick of <radical>dynamite</radical> is going to be <kanji>sick</kanji> forever. Unfortunately there are no medicines that are effective on sticks of dynamite, so once they contract a sickness, they’re sick for good.

Let the <radical>sun</radical> shine into your <radical>ear</radical> while sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> and make sure <kanji>most</kanji> of it gets in your head. You want to fill your brain with the most sun anyone ever has.

Look at the <radical>ground</radical>! You spilled some <radical>water</radical> <radical>drop</radical>s, so I <kanji>request</kanji> that you wipe them up. I'd do it myself, but you're the one who spilled them, so I'm requesting that you do it. Pretty reasonable request, right?

<radical>Angle</radical> your <radical>sword</radical> correctly at this <radical>cow</radical> to <kanji>solve</kanji> its riddle. The key is to <kanji>untie</kanji> the cow with the sword without hurting it.
Did you know that those strange <radical>geoduck</radical> creatures were once used to make <kanji>page</kanji>s? Okay maybe not, but it makes for a memorable image!
